Graphical abstract The controlled synthesis and exploration of the biomass valorization properties of organo-functionalized ionic-type polyoxometalates has been attracting considerable interest, but it still poses a challenge. Herein, three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-polyoxovanadates, [Pd(eIM)4][V6O16(eIM)4] (IPP-1), [Pd(mIM)4]2(H2V10O28)·3H2O (IPP-2) and [Pd(mIM)4]2(V4O12)·4H2O (IPP-3) (mIM = 1-methylimidazole, eIM = 1-ethylimidazole) with [V6O16(eIM)4]2-, [H2V10O28]4- and [V4O12]4- clusters were skillfully designed and successfully isolated, respectively. Importantly, IPP-1 represents the first ionic-type combination of a Pd-complex with an organo-functionalized {V6O16(eIM)4} cluster, and it exhibits remarkable catalytic activity towards the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), achieving an impressive conversion of 93 % and selectivity of 98 % under atmospheric O2. It can be reused at least five times without any loss of activity. Control experiments confirm that such exceptional catalytic activity originate from the cooperative effect between Pd-complex and {V6O16(eIM)4}. Based on spectroscopic results and density functional theory calculations, a plausible mechanism involving two parallel pathways has been proposed. Keywords Polyoxovanadates Organo-functionalization HMF oxidation Mechanism investigation DFT calculation Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Faced with the over-depletion of fossil fuels and severe environmental pollution, numerous scientists have redirected their efforts towards exploring sustainable resources [1,2]. Biomass-based fuels and platform chemicals, as the renewable and readily accessible sources, have emerged as highly promising alternatives to fossil-based feedstocks [3–5]. 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) is an important bio-platform chemical predominantly derived from the dehydration of carbohydrates (such as glucose and fructose). It holds great potential as a versatile raw material for synthesizing a diverse range of high value-add compounds through various pathways, including oxidation, reduction, hydrolysis, and more [6]. Through oxidation reaction, HMF can be transformed into 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), 5-hydroxymethyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (HMFCA), 5-formyl-2-furancarboxylic acid (FFCA), 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA) [7] (Scheme 1 ). In recent years, the selective oxidation of HMF to produce DFF has gained significant attention, owing to the importance of DFF as a vital building block in the synthesis of antifungals, pharmaceuticals, organic conductors, and other valuable compounds [8–10]. From the perspective of “Green Chemistry”, the selective oxidation of HMF to DFF by using O2 as sole oxidant is considered as a sustainable and cost-effective strategy to biomass utilization. However, the aerobic oxidation is a thermodynamically challenging process, primarily due to the high energy barrier required to activate molecular oxygen [11,12]. Moreover, the over-oxidation of the hydroxyl group and aldehyde group in HMF can lead to low selectivity towards the desired DFF product (Scheme 1). To tackle these issues, various homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed. Noble-metal catalysts, particularly the cases based on Pd, are widely employed to activate molecule oxygen and catalyze the aerobic oxidation of HMF [13–18]. Dong group has successfully immobilized ultrafine Pd nanoparticles on N-doped carbon nanospheres, and the resulting composites exhibited satisfactory catalytic activities for HMF oxidation with a turnover frequency (TOF) of 24.5 h−1 [13]. The utilization of a MnO2-supported single-atomic Pd catalyst enabled the complete conversion of HMF with O2 in aqueous solution [14]. Recently, several non-noble metal catalysts have emerged as promising candidate for the aerobic transformation of HMF [8,19–25]. Among them, vanadium-based compounds have exhibited remarkable catalytic performances [22–25]. For instance, VOSO4, in combined with Cu(NO3)2 in the homogeneous system, gave 99 % conversion of HMF and 99 % yield of DFF [22]. To facilitate catalyst recycling, active center V2O5 was immobilized onto zeolite. As a result, the H-beta zeolite-supported vanadate catalyst was found to be an efficient and reusable catalyst for selective production of DFF under 0.1 MPa O2 [23]. In addition, nitrogen doped carbon-supported V2O5 and NH4V3O8 were also successively reported for the oxidation of HMF to DFF with air as the sole oxidant [8,24]. As a fascinating group of early transition-metal (MoVI, WVI, VV, NbV and TaV) oxide-anion clusters, polyoxometalates (POMs) have been attracting significant attention in the field of catalysis by virtue of their tunable composition, remarkable redox activity, and high chemical and thermal stability [11,12,26–33]. Especially, polyoxovanadates (POVs), which represent a unique subfamily of POMs, have received continuous interest in aerobic oxidation reaction owing to the diverse coordination geometries and versatile redox activities of the vanadium ions [34–37]. Organo-functionalized POVs compounds, which integrate the distinctive features of vanadium-oxide clusters with the versatile functionalities of the organic species, show distinct advantages in the oxidation reactions [38–41]. In 2013, imidazole-functionalized hexavanadates, namely VV 6O15(mIM)8, VIV 2VV 4O14(mIM)8 and VIV 2VV 4O14(eIM)8 (mIM = 1-methylimidazole, eIM = 1-ethylimidazole), were synthesized in our group. Among these compounds, VIV 2VV 4O14(eIM)8 was found to be capable of activating molecular oxygen and promoting the selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols under 2 atm O2 pressure [42]. However, up to now, functionalized POVs have not been used as catalysts in aerobic oxidation of HMF. Compared with isolated POVs, coupling POV anions with metal complexes cations in catalyst design can not only combine the merits of both components and gain desirable catalytic behaviors, but also lead to the heterogenization of these catalysts [43]. Our group successfully combined the Pd-dpa (dpa = 2,2′-dipyridine amine) complex with alkoxohexavanadate, and the resulting [Pd(dpa)(acac)]2[V6O13(OMe)6] afforded excellent heterogeneous catalytic activity in the oxidation of benzyl-alkanes[44]. Based on the previous reports, it is reasonable to speculate that integrating metal complexes with organo-functionalized POVs is an intelligent strategy for developing highly efficient and durable catalysts for the aerobic oxidation of HMF. To advance our research on catalytic oxidation with POVs-based compounds, herein the Pd-complex was employed as counteraction to combine with imidazole-founctionalized POVs. As a result, three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-polyoxovanadates (Pd-POVs), [Pd(eIM)4][V6O16(eIM)4] (IPP-1), [Pd(mIM)4]2(H2V10O28)·3H2O (IPP-2) and [Pd(mIM)4]2(V4O12)·4H2O (IPP-3), were isolated by carefully controlling the reaction conditions. Especially, owing to the coexisting of Pd-complex cation and functionalized {V6O16(eIM)4} anion, IPP-1 exhibits remarkable catalytic activity towards the aerobic oxidation of HMF under ambient pressure. The ingenious solidification the catalytically active {V6O16(eIM)4} and {Pd(eIM)4} within an ionic crystalline solid has endowed IPP-1 with exceptional heterogeneity and durability. In addition, systematic mechanism study was conducted by control experiments and theoretical calculations. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials and methods The mojority of chemicals were obtained from commercial source, except for V6O14(mIM)8 [42] and (VO)(mIM)4SO4 [45], which were synthesized following the methods described in previous reports. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns were obtained using a Shimadzu XRD-6000 diffractometer with Cu Kα X-ray radiation (λ = 0.154056 nm), operating at 50 mA current and 40 kV voltage. The Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded with a Bruker ALPHA spectrometer over the range of 4000–400 cm−1. The X-ray photoelectron spectrum (XPS) were acquired using a PHI VersaProbe III spectrometer (Al Kα irradiation). The content of C, H, and N in Pd-POVs were determined using an ElementarVario EL cube Elmer CHN elemental analyzer, while ICP-MS was performed on a ThermoiCAP 6000 atomic emission spectrometer to quantify Pd and V. High performance liquid chromatography (HPLC) spectra of the products were analyzed by a 2998 PDA Detector (Waters e2695). The gas chromatographic (GC) analyses were conducted on Shimadzu GC-2014C which equipped with an FID detector. The 1H NMR spectra were recorded on a Bruker 400 MHz instrument, using CDCl3 as the solvent and tetramethylsilane as internal reference. 2.2 Synthesis of the imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-POV compounds Synthesis of [Pd(eIM)4][V6O16(eIM)4] (IPP-1). V2O5 (0.25 g, 1.37 mmol) and eIM (3 mL) were dissolved in water (10 mL) to form a slurry, which was stirred at room temperature for 60 min. Then, Pd(OAc)2 (0.05 g, 0.22 mmol) was added into the solution, and the resulting mixture was stirred for 12 h at 60 °C. The reaction mixture was filtered after cooling to room temperature, and the yellow crystals were obtained by allowing the solution to stand for one week. Yield: 68 % for IPP-1 based on V2O5. A mixture of HMF (0.25 mmol), catalyst (5 mg), and chlorobenzene (2 mL) were added to a Shrek tube fitted with an O2 balloon and a magnetic stirrer. The reaction mixture was heated to 90 °C for 12 h, and after cooling to room temperature, the solid catalyst was separated by centrifugation and the filtrate was quantitative analysed by GC and HPLC. Recycle test of IPP-1. The reusability of IPP-1 was tested in five consecutive recycling experiments for the selective oxidation of HMF. After each reaction, the catalyst IPP-1 was separated by centrifugation and washed with chlorobenzene and ethanol for three times. Then, the solid was dried under vacuum at 70 °C for 2 h and reused in the subsequent run. 2.4 X-ray crystallography The crystallographic data of the three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-polyoxovanadates were collected using a Bruker APEX-II DUO CCD single-crystal diffractometer with Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at a temperature of 296 K. The structure of the three IPPs were solved through direct methods, and further refined using full-matrix least-squares refinements on F2 with the SHELXL-97 program [46]. All non-H atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters. The detailed crystallographic data for the three compounds are listed in Table S1-S4. 2.5 Density functional theory (DFT) calculations DFT calculations were carried out using the PBE0 DFT functional [47]. The geometry optimizations for C, H, N, O were based on 6–311 g* level, while those for Pd and V were based on Lanl2DZ, D3 dispersion correction developed by Grimme is included for weak interactions [48]. All of the DFT calculations were conducted using the Gaussian 16 package, with the resolution of identity approximation employed [49]. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Synthesis and structure of the IPP compounds To controllably combine the POVs anions with Pd-complex cations and construct ionic organic–inorganic compounds, we employed V2O5 and Pd(OAc)2 as raw materials to react with organic ligands (mIM or eIM). The synthetic methodology is outlined in Scheme 2 . Using eIM as ligand led to the formation of a functionalized IPP-1, while replacing eIM with mIM resulted in the generation of IPP-2 containing decavanadate. By following a similar method to that used for IPP-2, but adding triethylamine as an additional organic base, IPP-3 was isolated. Triethylamine increases the alkalinity of the reaction system, promoting the formation of the [V4O12]4- unit [44]. The experimental results mentioned above suggest that the basicity of the reaction system and the length of alkyl chain on imidazole ligand are essential for the assembly of the organic–inorganic hybrids. By carefully controlling the synthetic conditions, the Pd-complex was successfully combined with a series of POV anion skeletons. Single crystal X-ray diffraction (SXRD) analysis confirms that IPP-1 crystallizes in the P 1 ¯ space group of the triclinic system. As illustrated in Fig. 1 , the molecular unit of IPP-1 contains of one [Pd(mIM)4]2+ cation and one [V6O16(eIM)4]2+ anion. The cation part of IPP-1 features a Pd2+ ion coordinated by four N atoms from four eIm ligands, and it presents a nearly square-planar geometry (Fig. 1b). The average length of Pd-N bond is 2.0047(79) Å, which is consistent with the value reported in literature [44]. The [V6O16(eIM)4]2- anion is composed of one central {V4O12} unit and two vanadyl complexes, which are connected by two bridging μ2-O atoms (Fig. 1c). From the structure perspective, the [V6O16(eIM)4]2- anion is similar to a neural V6O14(eIM)8 previously reported by some of us [43], but there are three distinct differences. Firstly, in the [V6O16(eIM)4]2- anion, the {V4O12} unit is attached by two trigonal bipyramid [VO3N2] groups (the V atom is coordinated by two N atoms from two eIM ligands, one bridging μ2-O atom and two terminal O atoms) on opposite sides, whereas two octahedral [VO2N4] groups (the V canter is coordinated by four N atoms from four eIM ligands, one bridging μ2-O atom and one terminal O atom) are connected to the {V4O12} ring in V6O14(eIM)8 (Fig. 1d and S1). Secondly, all the V atoms in IPP-1 have an oxidation state of + 5, as confirmed by bond valence sum (BVS) calculations and XPS measurements (Table S3 and Figure S2). In contrast, the mixed-valence {V2 IVVV 4} unit was detected in V6O14(eIM)8. Thirdly, because of the different oxidation states and coordination geometries of V atoms, V6O14(eIM)8 is a neutral compound, while [V6O16(eIM)4]2- is negatively charged. As a result, IPP-1 was isolated through the electrostatic interaction between [V6O16(eIM)4]2- and [Pd(eIM)4]2+. To our knowledge, IPP-1 represents the first case of a functionalized ionic organic–inorganic hybrid, in which both of metal cation and polyoxoanion are functionalized with eIM ligands. SXRD analysis reveal that the asymmetric unit of IPP-2 is composed of one [H2V10O28]4- anion, two [Pd(mIM)]2+ cations, and three crystal water molecules (Figure S3). The cations in IPP-2 are identical to those in IPP-1, and the classic [V10O28]6- ion is formed by close-packed ten {VO6} octahedra. It should be note that two protons are added to the {V10O28} skeleton to achieve charge balance. The BVS calculations show that the oxidation states of V and Pd are + 5 and + 2 (Table S3), respectively. The detail bond lengths and bond angles data are summarized in Table S2. Crystallographic data prove that IPP-3 constructed from two [Pd(mIM)4]2+ cations, one [V4O12]4- anion and four crystal water molecules (Figure S4). The [V4O12]4- unit is composed of four corner-shared {VO4} tetrahedra, forming an eight-numbered [V4O4] ring with chair-like geometry. Similar to the case in IPP-1, the Pd2+ ion in IPP-3 is coordinated by four N atoms from four mIM ligands, leading to a square-planar {PdN4} coordination geometry. Moreover, the oxidation states of V and Pd were calculated to be + 5 and + 2 (Table S3), respectively. The experimental PXRD patterns of all the three samples matched well with the simulated patterns from SXRD, providing evidence for the phase purity of the products (Figure S5-S7). Since the three ionic organic–inorganic hybrids show similar FT-IR spectra (Figure S8-S10), only the characteristic absorption peaks of IPP-1 were analysed here. As shown in Figure S8, the bands at 860 cm−1 can be assigned to the vibration of V = Ot, and the V-Ob-V vibrations are detected at 777 cm−1. The characteristic peaks in the 448–492 cm−1 region are attributed to the stretching vibration of Pd-N bonds. Additionally, the absorption peaks in the range of 1664–1111 cm−1 belong to the vibration of C = N and C = C in imidazole ring, and the characteristic –CH2- and –CH3 group is observed around 3096 cm−1. 3.2 Catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF under ambient pressure Since both the Pd-based compounds and functionalized POVs have demonstrated satisfactory catalytic performance in aerobic oxidation reaction, we anticipated that the obtained three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-POVs could exhibit catalytic activity in oxidation of HMF to DFF using O2 as oxidant. In a typical reaction, HMF, naphthalene (internal standard), and catalyst were dispersed in chlorobenzene, and the oxidation reaction was carried out under an O2 atmosphere. After systematically optimizing the reaction conditions (Figure S11, S12 and Table S4), it was achieved that over 93 % of HMF was converted to DFF with a selectivity of 98 % in the presence of IPP-1 (Fig. 2 b and Table 1 , entry 1). The turnover frequency (TOF) is calculated to be 13.7 h−1. Moreover, the HPLC-MS analysis confirms that the reaction system does not contain any over-oxidation products, such as HMFCA, FDCA or FFCA (Figure S13), even when the reaction time is prolonged to 24 h. The negligible conversion of HMF (15 %, Table 1, entry 8) in the blank test indicates the crucial catalytic role played by IPP-1. Fig. 2c illustrates the kinetic behavior of IPP-1, which was monitored at intervals of 2 h under optimal conditions. The plot of ln(Ct/C0) against reaction time shows a linear relationship with an R2 value of 99.16. The fitted curve demonstrates a pseudo-first-order kinetic process described by the equation ln(Ct/C0) = -kt, where the value of reaction rate constant k is calculated to be 0.0226 h−1. To our knowledge, this presents the first example of catalytic oxidation of HMF by using a the functionalized ionic organic–inorganic hybrid. Comparatively, IPP-2 (Conv. of HMF: 68 %; Sele. of DFF: 60 %) and IPP-3 (Conv. of HMF: 76 %; Sele. of DFF: 71 %) give only moderate performance to the oxidation transformation (Table 1, entries 2 and 3). Therefore, due to its superior performance, IPP-1 was selected as a representative catalyst for the subsequent investigations. Next, we studied the heterogeneity and durability of the IPP-1 catalyst. After reaching a conversion of about 30 %, the solid catalyst was filtered from the mixture, and the oxidation reaction was allowed to continue under the turnover conditions for an additional 10 h. As shown in Fig. 2d, only a slight increase of DFF was detected after filtration, and the increment was comparable to that observed in the blank experiment. These findings indicate the intrinsic heterogeneity of IPP-1. Subsequently, the catalytic performance of IPP-1 was evaluated over five successive cycles. After each run, the spent catalyst was separated from the reaction system, washed with chlorobenzene and ethanol for 3 times, and dried at 70 °C before being reused in the next run. The result, as shown in Fig. 2e, indicates that the catalytic performance of IPP-1 remained consistent over the five cycles, with the conversion of HMF maintained above 90 % and the selectivity of DFF kept above 96 %. We speculate that the ingenious solidification the catalytically active {V6O16(eIM)4} and {Pd(eIM)4} within an ionic crystalline solid effectively prevents active site aggregation, and this endows IPP-1 with excellent heterogeneity and durability. More importantly, the molecular structure of IPP-1 retained intact after the recycling experiment, as illustrated by the comparable FT-IR spectra of the fresh IPP-1 and the used catalyst (Figure S15). Compared with most catalytic materials, the unique advantage of IPP-1 is the ability to promote the aerobic oxidation under atmospheric pressure. In addition, the catalytic performance of IPP-1 is comparable to and even superior to that of both noble and non-noble catalysts [15,19,20,23,30,32,50–55]. The detail comparisons are summarised in Table S5. To investigate the influence of each individual component on the aerobic oxidation reaction, several control experiments were conducted under the standard reaction conditions. Although Pd(OAc)2 achieved a conversion of 85 %, the selectivity towards DFF was only 23 % (Table 1, entry 4). Additionally, a color change in the reaction mixture, from orange to dark green, demonstrates that the Pd sites underwent reduction during the oxidation of HMF and were not re-oxidized under the ambient conditions. Similarly, V2O5 also gave a moderate conversion (75 %) and inferior selectivity (15 %, Table 1, entry 5). These results suggest that although the Pd and V sites in IPP-1 can effectively enhance the conversion of HMF, they make little contribution to the selectivity. Employing the functionalized hexavanadate V6O14(eIM)8 [42] as catalyst in a homogeneous system resulted in an almost complete conversion of HMF, with a selectivity of 75 % (Table 1, entry 6). This indicates that incorporating imidazole groups into the functionalized POVs is essential for enhancing the catalytic performance. In addition, the oxidation state of V was found to be + 5 after the catalytic reaction (Figure S16), demonstrating that the functionalized V species can undergo oxidation under atmospheric O2. To further insight into the role of imidazole groups in the aerobic reaction, a catalyst (VO)(mIM)4SO4 [45], which structurally resembles the [VO3(eIM)2] group in IPP-1, was synthesized and employed. Despite the conversion of HMF was only 48 %, a satisfactory yield of DFF (88 %) was achieved (Table 1, entry 7). According to the above control experiments, we speculate that the {V4O12} ring and {Pd(eIM)4} complex are responsible for enhancing the conversion rate, and the functionalized [VO3(eIM)2] group in IPP-1 contributes to the improvement of DFF selectivity. In exploring the reaction mechanism of the aerobic oxidation process, it is important to consider the role of IPP-1. Specifically, it is necessary to determine whether the catalyst activates O2 and produces active oxygen species or directly interacts with HMF molecules. To answer this question, some control experiments were designed and carried out. According to previous reports, active oxide radials such as superoxide ·O2 – and hydroxyl radical ·OH have been generally proposed when molecular oxygen is used as an oxidant [56,57]. Thus, some radical scavengers including 2,6-di-tert-butyl-4-methylphenol and 1,4-benzoquinone (for ·O2 –), as well as diphenylamine and tert-butyl alcohol (for ·OH) were added in the reaction system, respectively. Even with the addition of these radical scavengers in the aerobic oxidation system, the conversion of HMF remained above 80 % (Fig. 3 a), proving that IPP-1 does not directly activate O2 through a radical mechanism. To explore the interaction between IPP-1 and the substrate, the adsorption experiment was performed. As illustrated in Figure S17, IPP-1 is capable of adsorbing HMF, achieving an adsorption amount of 0.36 mgHMF/mgcat. after 80 min. We hypothesize that the O atom of POVs and N atom of imidazole group can form hydrogen bonds with the hydroxy group on HMF, which may favour the activation of HMF [58]. Then, the catalytic reaction was conducted under N2 atmosphere to further study the reaction between IPP-1 and HMF. Fig. 3b exhibits that the conversion of HMF increased up to 40 % as the reaction time was extended to 80 min, and it remained almost unchanged even through further prolonged the reaction time to 2 h. Interestingly, upon blowing O2 into the reaction mixture, HMF was rapidly transformed to DFF and reached a maximum conversion of 91 %. This result proves that IPP-1 can directly oxidize HMF to DFF under anaerobic environment. During this process, IPP-1 underwent reduction and lost the oxidizing capacity. After pouring O2, the reduced IPP-1 was re-oxidized and regained its oxidizing ability. To further insight the change in oxidation states of the catalyst during the oxidation transformation, the XPS measurements were conducted on the recovered IPP-1 under N2 atmosphere and after blowing O2. The high-resolution XPS spectrum of Pd 3d (Fig. 3c) revealed two peaks at 343.6 eV (Pd 3d3/2) and 338.4 eV (Pd 3d5/2), which correspond to the + 2 oxidation state of Pd [59]. Additionally, two peaks located at 342.2 (Pd 3d3/2) and 337.0 (Pd 3d5/2) were observed, indicating the presence of Pd0 in the recovered catalyst. These results suggest that the Pd sites were partially reduced during the oxidation of HMF under N2 atmosphere. Likewise, partial reduction of V5+ to V4+ was also occurred as both V4+ (binding energy: 523.4 eV for V4+ 2p1/2 and 516.0 eV for V4+ 2p3/2) and V5+ (binding energy: 524.3 eV for V5+ 2p1/2 and 516.9 eV for V5+ 2p3/2) species were observed in the high-resolution XPS spectrum of V (Fig. 3d) [44]. Upon pouring O2 into the reaction system, only the V5+ (binding energy: 5.24 eV for V2p1/2 and 516.9 eV for V2p1/2) and Pd2+ (binding energy: 343.6 eV for Pd 3d3/2 and 338.4 eV for Pd 3d5/2) was detected (Fig. 3e and 3f), indicating that the reduced IPP-1 was re-oxidized with O2. DFT calculations were performed to gain a comprehensive understanding of the interaction between the active catalytic sites in IPP-1 and the substrate during the oxidation process. Previous studies have indicated that this process involves the adsorption/coordination of HMF on the active species, followed by the abstraction of the hydroxyl H atom to generate OHC(C4H2O)CH2O* (* denotes the intermediate species), cleavage of the benzyloxy Cα-H bond, and subsequent desorption of the produced OHC(C4H2O)CHO [60]. By computing the energy barriers for each step and optimizing the structures of HMF oxidation with Pd and V sites (as depicted in Fig. 4 ), it was determined that the rate-determining step in the oxidation reaction is the hydroxyl H atom abstraction and OHC(C4H2O)CH2O intermediate generation. The energy barriers for Pd and V sites were found to be 0.78 and 1.53 eV, respectively, both of which are lower than the blank test (2.24 eV). Based on these calculations, it can be concluded that both the Pd and V sites contribute to accelerating the transformation of HMF to DFF. Additionally, the oxidative transformation is more favourable at the Pd sites compared to the V sites, primarily due to the lower energy barrier for the hydroxyl H atom abstraction step. On the basis of experimental results and DFT theoretical calculations, a plausible oxidation mechanism was proposed (Fig. 5 ), which was considered to involve two parallel pathways. In pathway I, upon adsorption on the surface of IPP-1, the HMF molecule is oxidized by the [PdII(eIM)4]2+ cation over a proton coupled electron transfer process [33]. The hydroxyl proton is transferred from HMF to the bridging oxygen of [V6 VO16(eIM)4]2- to generate DFF. Simultaneously, the electrons are transferred to the active Pd center, forming a reduced Pd0 species (intermediate A). Notably, the coordination between palladium and eIM prevented the formation of Pd black during this process. And then, the resulting Pd0 species is reoxidized by V5+ sites, leading to the production of species B via intramolecular electron transfer. Our control experiment provided evidence that the V5+ species was capable of oxidizing Pd0 to Pd2+ (Figure S18). Finally, the V4+ sites is reoxidized by O2, affording [PdII(eIM)4][V6 VO16(eIM)4] and completing the catalytic cycle. Alternatively, the HMF molecule can be directly oxidized by the [V6 VO16(eIM)4]2- anion (through a proton coupled electron transfer process), resulting in the generation of reduced V4+ species B (pathway II), which is then oxidized by O2 to realize the regeneration and circulation. In order to evaluate the scope of the imidazole-functionalized Pd-POVs, oxidation of benzyl alcohol and its derivatives were conducted using IPP-1 as a catalyst. Encouragingly, IPP-1 also exhibits catalytic activity in the aerobic oxidation of these aromatic alcohols to the aldehydes with the conversions of 91–95 % and the selectivities of 96–98 % (Table S6). These results highlight the wide-ranging applicability of the imidazole-functionalized IPP-1 as an effective catalyst for oxidation reactions. 4 Conclusions In summary, three IPPs with different POV anions are successfully prepared for the catalytic oxidation of HMF to DFF. As a dual-active catalyst with Pd-complex and imidazole-functionalized POV, IPP-1 exhibits excellent catalytic properties with 93 % HMF conversion and 98 % selectivity towards DFF under atmospheric pressure. In addition, IPP-1 also establishes the satisfactory catalytic stability and recyclability after five cycles. More importantly, well-designed control experiments and DFT calculations insightful indicate that both Pd-complex and the organic-functionalized {V6O16(eIM)4} cluster contribute to the excellent catalytic performance. Moreover, we propose a plausible oxidation mechanism consisting of two parallel pathways. This work represents a significant advancement in the development of catalytically active crystalline organic-functionalized polyoxometalates, which holds promise for facilitating the efficient conversion of biomass chemicals into valuable products. coredata.dc:description: The controlled synthesis and exploration of the biomass valorization properties of organo-functionalized ionic-type polyoxometalates has been attracting considerable interest, but it still poses a challenge. Herein, three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-polyoxovanadates, [Pd(eIM)4][V6O16(eIM)4] (IPP-1), [Pd(mIM)4]2(H2V10O28)·3H2O (IPP-2) and [Pd(mIM)4]2(V4O12)·4H2O (IPP-3) (mIM = 1-methylimidazole, eIM = 1-ethylimidazole) with [V6O16(eIM)4]2-, [H2V10O28]4- and [V4O12]4- clusters were skillfully designed and successfully isolated, respectively. Importantly, IPP-1 represents the first ionic-type combination of a Pd-complex with an organo-functionalized {V6O16(eIM)4} cluster, and it exhibits remarkable catalytic activity towards the aerobic oxidation of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural (HMF) to 2,5-diformylfuran (DFF), achieving an impressive conversion of 93 % and selectivity of 98 % under atmospheric O2. It can be reused at least five times without any loss of activity. Control experiments confirm that such exceptional catalytic activity originate from the cooperative effect between Pd-complex and {V6O16(eIM)4}. Based on spectroscopic results and density functional theory calculations, a plausible mechanism involving two parallel pathways has been proposed.
coredata.dc:title: Rational fabrication of three imidazole-functionalized ionic-type Pd-Polyoxovanadates for aerobic oxidation of 5-Hydroxymethulfurfural to 2,5-Diformylfuran
